pullRequest.body:
This PR defines the Weyl group of a root pairing, and its permutation representation on the indexing set of roots.

Co-authored-by: Deepro Choudhury

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

:v: ScottCarnahan can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10459968831/job/28965119992)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10459968831/job/28965119304)
Thanks! Some formal comments:

I still have reservations about this as the definition of the Weyl group but I think we can proceed for now and see how we get on.

I think a very desirable property of the definitions and associated API is to maintain perfect symmetry between roots and coroots. I worked quite hard initially to set things up so that this could be the case. So the definition here breaks that and raise the question about what is the Weyl group for the coroots?

I'm tempted to say that the examples where the permutation representation is not faithful do not deserve to be regarded as root pairings. If we added an axiom which forced faithfulness then we could define the Weyl group as a subgroup of permutations and continue with a symmetric API.

Notwithstanding all the above, I have run out of time to think about this in detail and what you have proposed is certainly sensible so I think we can proceed. Characterising when `weylGroupToPerm` has trivial kernel seems like a priority to me now.

Anyway, thanks for doing all this. I've left a few minor suggestions but otherwise LGTM.

bors d+
Thanks! Some formal comments:

I still have reservations about this as the definition of the Weyl group but I think we can proceed for now and see how we get on.

I think a very desirable property of the definitions and associated API is to maintain perfect symmetry between roots and coroots. I worked quite hard initially to set things up so that this could be the case. So the definition here breaks that and raise the question about what is the Weyl group for the coroots?

I'm tempted to say that the examples where the permutation representation is not faithful do not deserve to be regarded as root pairings. If we added an axiom which forced faithfulness then we could define the Weyl group as a subgroup of permutations and continue with a symmetric API.

Notwithstanding all the above, I have run out of time to think about this in detail and what you have proposed is certainly sensible so I think we can proceed. Characterising when `weylGroupToPerm` has trivial kernel seems like a priority to me now.

Anyway, thanks for doing all this. I've left a few minor suggestions but otherwise LGTM.

bors d+

```suggestion
lemma reflection_inv :
```

```suggestion
  Subgroup.closure ({ reflection P i | i :  })
```
Consider pointing to some background. (Wikipedia?)

```suggestion
lemma reflection_mem_weylGroup : P.reflection i  P.weylGroup :=
```
Does the `induction` tactic not work with this theorem?

Given that we're adding this, I think we should also add:
```lean
@[simp]
lemma reflection_sq :
    P.reflection i ^ 2 = 1 :=
  mul_eq_one_iff_eq_inv.mpr rfl

@[simp]
lemma reflection_perm_sq :
    P.reflection_perm i ^ 2 = 1 := by
  ext j
  have : P.reflection i (P.reflection i (P.root j)) = P.root j := by simp [ sq, P.reflection_sq i]
  rwa [ root_reflection_perm,  root_reflection_perm, EmbeddingLike.apply_eq_iff_eq] at this

@[simp]
lemma reflection_perm_inv :
    (P.reflection_perm i) = P.reflection_perm i :=
  (mul_eq_one_iff_eq_inv.mp <| P.reflection_perm_sq i).symm
```
and also the corresponding two lemmas for `coreflection` to keep the API symmetric.

Depending on the outcome of my remarks about the definition of the Weyl group, this lemma might become redundant. However if we do keep it (or something similar) I think we could factor out some smaller results as follows:
```lean
-- This would go next to `Subgroup.closure` API (naming possibly not ideal).
-- Looks like sort of lemma Coxeter group people might want anyway
lemma Subgroup.smul_mem_of_mem_closure_of_mem
    {G X : Type*} [Group G] [MulAction G X] (s : Set G) (t : Set X)
    (hs :  g  s, g  s) (hst :  (g  s) (x  t), g  x  t)
    {g : G} (hg : g  Subgroup.closure s) {x : X} (hx : x  t) :
    g  x  t := by
  induction hg using Subgroup.closure_induction'' generalizing x with
  | one => simpa
  | mem g' hg' => exact hst g' hg' x hx
  | inv_mem g' hg' => exact hst g' (hs g' hg') x hx
  | mul _ _ _ _ h h => rw [mul_smul]; exact h (h hx)

-- If we add this, we should also add the coroot / coreflection version
lemma mem_range_root_of_mem_range_reflection_of_mem_range_root
    {r : M [R] M} { : M} (hr : r  range P.reflection) (h :   range P.root) :
    r    range P.root := by
  obtain i, rfl := hr
  obtain j, rfl := h
  exact P.reflection_perm i j, P.root_reflection_perm i j

-- I claim `w  P.weylGroup` rather than `w : P.weylGroup` will usually be more convenient
lemma exists_root_eq_smul_of_mem_weylGroup {w : M [R] M} (hw : w  P.weylGroup) (i : ) :
     j, P.root j = w  P.root i :=
  Subgroup.smul_mem_of_mem_closure_of_mem (range P.reflection) (range P.root) (by simp)
    (fun _ h _  P.mem_range_root_of_mem_range_reflection_of_mem_range_root h) hw (mem_range_self i)
```

I was expecting to see:
```lean
def weylGroup : Subgroup (  ) := Subgroup.closure <| range P.reflection_perm
```
together with:
```lean
-- Naming TBD
def weylGroup.toRootEquiv : P.weylGroup * M [R] M := sorry

def weylGroup.toCorootEquiv : P.weylGroup * N [R] N := sorry
```
What do you think?

Also, there is a mathematical point I need to think about. Specifically, the following is true:
```lean
lemma reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff :
    P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j 
     x  span R (range P.root), P.reflection i x = P.reflection j x := by
  refine fun h x hx  ?_, fun h  ?_
   induction hx using Submodule.span_induction' with
    | mem x hx =>
      obtain k, rfl := hx
      simp only [ root_reflection_perm, h]
    | zero => simp
    | add x _ y _ hx hy => simp [hx, hy]
    | smul t x _ hx => simp [hx]
   ext k
    apply P.root.injective
    simp [h (P.root k) (Submodule.subset_span <| mem_range_self k)]
```
This gives us what we need for root systems. However what about if the roots don't span? It's not immediately clear to me whether this might hold in general:
```lean
lemma reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff' :
    P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j  P.reflection i = P.reflection j := by
  refine fun h  ?_, fun h  Equiv.ext fun k  P.root.injective <| by simp [h]
  sorry
```

The definition you suggest would be a substantial improvement, if I could prove that it worked (i.e., that the permutation representation is always faithful).  I'm still thinking about that, so perhaps this PR was a bit premature.

I had a few minutes this morning and decided to thought a bit more about `reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff'`. I believe the following is true:
```lean
lemma reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff' [CharZero R] [IsDomain R] [NoZeroSMulDivisors R M]
    (hij : P.pairing j i  0) :
    P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j  P.reflection i = P.reflection j := by
```
because if $$r_i$$ and $$r_j$$ are the two reflections and $$n_{ij}$$ are the pairing constants, then:
$$r_i = r_j \iff \alpha_i^* \otimes\alpha_i = \alpha_j^*\otimes\alpha_j \iff n_{ii}n_{ji}\alpha_i^*\otimes\alpha_i = n_{ii}n_{ji}\alpha_j^*\otimes\alpha_j $$
and:
$$n_{ii}n_{ji}\alpha_i^*\otimes\alpha_i = (n_{ii}\alpha_i^*) \otimes (n_{ji}\alpha_i) = (n_{ji}\alpha_j^*) \otimes (n_{jj}\alpha_j)$$
because the ith and jth permutations agree.

It also seems to me that we can prove the result for finite reduced root pairings. Sorry that's rather rushed, I probably won't have time to think about this again for a few days (by which time you may have had a chance to return to it and sort it all out).

Unfortunately I have to start work now.
That's great.  So far, I've been able to show that `Injective fun (x : M) => (2 : R)  x` implies the equivalence.

I had a few minutes over lunch and managed to prove:
```lean
lemma reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff [CharZero R] [IsDomain R] [NoZeroSMulDivisors R M] :
    P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j  P.reflection i = P.reflection j := by
  refine fun h  ?_, fun h  Equiv.ext fun k  P.root.injective <| by simp [h]
  have hr : P.pairing j i  P.root i = P.pairing j j  P.root j := by
    have : P.reflection i (P.root j) = P.reflection j (P.root j) := by
      simp only [ root_reflection_perm, h]
    simpa only [reflection, Module.reflection_apply, sub_right_inj]
  have hc : P.pairing i i  P.coroot i = P.pairing j i  P.coroot j := by
    have : (P.coreflection i) (P.coroot i) = (P.coreflection j) (P.coroot i) := by
      simp only [ coroot_reflection_perm, h]
    simpa only [coreflection, Module.reflection_apply, sub_right_inj]
  have hij : 2 * P.pairing j i  0 := by
    suffices P.pairing j i  0 by simpa
    exact fun contra  P.ne_zero j <| by simpa [contra, eq_comm (a := (0 : M))] using hr
  suffices (2 * P.pairing j i)  (P.flip.toLin (P.coroot i)).smulRight (P.root i) =
           (2 * P.pairing j i)  (P.flip.toLin (P.coroot j)).smulRight (P.root j) by
    simpa [reflection, Module.reflection, Module.preReflection] using
      smul_right_injective (M := M [R] M) hij this
  suffices (P.flip.toLin (P.pairing i i  P.coroot i)).smulRight (P.pairing j i  P.root i) =
           (P.flip.toLin (P.pairing j i  P.coroot j)).smulRight (P.pairing j j  P.root j) by
    ext x
    replace this := LinearMap.congr_fun this x
    simp only [pairing_same, map_smul,  mul_smul, LinearMap.coe_smulRight, LinearMap.smul_apply,
      smul_eq_mul] at this 
    convert this using 2 <;> ring
  rw [hr, hc]

lemma _root_.RootSystem.reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff (P : RootSystem  R M N) (i j : ) :
    P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j  P.reflection i = P.reflection j := by
  refine fun h  ?_, fun h  Equiv.ext fun k  P.root.injective <| by simp [h]
  ext x
  have hx : x  span R (range P.root) := by simp [P.span_eq_top]
  induction hx using Submodule.span_induction' with
  | mem x hx =>
    obtain k, rfl := hx
    simp only [ root_reflection_perm, h]
  | zero => simp
  | add x _ y _ hx hy => simp [hx, hy]
  | smul t x _ hx => simp [hx]
```
The fact that there doesn't seem to be a perfect unification of assumptions makes me wonder if we should add an axiom to `RootPairing` (though it's premature to do so now I think).

> That's great. So far, I've been able to show that `Injective fun (x : M) => (2 : R)  x` implies the equivalence.

Oh this is great. Note:
```lean
example [CharZero R] [NoZeroSMulDivisors R M] :
    Injective fun (x : M) => (2 : R)  x :=
  smul_right_injective _ two_ne_zero
```

Alternatively this is `IsSMulRegular M (2 : R)`.

Specifically, I have a proof (not too far from your argument) that 
`P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j   (x : M), 2  (P.reflection i x -  P.reflection j x) = 0`
Also, I found a counterexample in char 2. Let `i j` be the only roots, linearly independent, with `P.reflection_perm` acting trivially. If we extend `M` suitably, we can take some `x` on which `P.reflection i x = x` and `P.reflection j x  x`.
In light of the non-faithfulness of the permutation representation in general, I think it is best to keep the current definition of `weylGroup`.

Nitpick:
```suggestion
  Subgroup.closure { P.reflection i | i :  }
```
(or even `Subgroup.closure (range P.reflection)` if you like)

```suggestion
    (fun _ h _  P.mem_range_root_of_mem_range_reflection_of_mem_range_root h) hw (mem_range_self i)
```

I appreciate that you added this in response to a request for a reference but IMHO no reference is better than Wikipedia.
```suggestion
by reflections in roots. -/
```

```suggestion
  toFun w :=
  { toFun := fun i => (P.exists_root_eq_smul_of_mem_weylGroup w.2 i).choose
```

```suggestion
  map_one' := by ext; simp
```

Let's characterise the range:
```suggestion

@[simp]
lemma range_weylGroupToPerm :
    P.weylGroupToPerm.range = Subgroup.closure (range P.reflection_perm) := by
  refine (Subgroup.closure_eq_of_le _ ?_ ?_).symm
   rintro - i, rfl
    simpa only [ weylGroupToPerm_apply_reflection] using mem_range_self _
   rintro - w, hw, rfl
    induction hw using Subgroup.closure_induction'' with
    | one =>
      change P.weylGroupToPerm 1  _
      simpa only [map_one] using Subgroup.one_mem _
    | mem w' hw' =>
      obtain i, rfl := hw'
      simpa only [weylGroupToPerm_apply_reflection] using Subgroup.subset_closure (mem_range_self i)
    | inv_mem w' hw' =>
      obtain i, rfl := hw'
      simpa only [reflection_inv, weylGroupToPerm_apply_reflection] using
        Subgroup.subset_closure (mem_range_self i)
    | mul w w hw hw h h =>
      simpa only [ Submonoid.mk_mul_mk _ w w hw hw, map_mul] using Subgroup.mul_mem _ h h

```

```suggestion
  (mul_eq_one_iff_eq_inv.mp <| P.reflection_perm_sq i).symm
  
```

I think it's better to state this in a less extensional way (no `x`). Furthermore I think this is the sort of proof for which `calc` is great:
```suggestion
lemma two_nsmul_reflection_eq_of_perm_eq (hij : P.reflection_perm i = P.reflection_perm j) :
    2  (P.reflection i) = 2  P.reflection j := by
  ext x
  suffices 2  P.toLin x (P.coroot i)  P.root i = 2  P.toLin x (P.coroot j)  P.root j by
    simpa [reflection_apply]
  calc 2  P.toLin x (P.coroot i)  P.root i
      = P.toLin x (P.coroot i)  ((2 : R)  P.root i) := ?_
    _ = P.toLin x (P.coroot i)  (P.pairing i j  P.root j) := ?_
    _ = P.toLin x (P.pairing i j  P.coroot i)  (P.root j) := ?_
    _ = P.toLin x ((2 : R)  P.coroot j)  (P.root j) := ?_
    _ = 2  P.toLin x (P.coroot j)  P.root j := ?_
   rw [smul_comm,  Nat.cast_smul_eq_nsmul R, Nat.cast_ofNat]
   rw [P.pairing_smul_root_eq j i i hij.symm, pairing_same]
   rw [ smul_comm,  smul_assoc, map_smul]
   rw [ P.pairing_smul_coroot_eq j i j hij.symm, pairing_same]
   rw [map_smul, smul_assoc,  Nat.cast_smul_eq_nsmul R, Nat.cast_ofNat]
```

After the changes above:
```suggestion
  suffices (P.reflection i) = (P.reflection j) from DFunLike.coe_injective this
  replace h2 : IsSMulRegular (M  M) 2 := IsSMulRegular.pi fun _  h2
  exact h2 <| P.two_nsmul_reflection_eq_of_perm_eq i j h
```

```suggestion
  exact (P.reflection_perm_eq_reflection_perm_iff_of_span i j).mp h x <| by simp [P.span_eq_top]
```

Better yet, add
```lean
attribute [simp] RootSystem.span_eq_top
```
just below the definition of `RootSystem` (line 116) and then no need to supply `P.span_eq_top` to `simp` here.

I think a very desirable property of the definitions and associated API is to maintain perfect symmetry between roots and coroots.
